speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Enter AJAX, armed; AGAMEMNON, ACHILLES, PATROCLUS, MENELAUS, ULYSSES, NESTOR, and others

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Here art thou in appointment fresh and fair,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Anticipating time with starting courage.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Give with thy trumpet a loud note to Troy,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Thou dreadful Ajax; that the appalled air

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: May pierce the head of the great combatant

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: And hale him hither.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Thou, trumpet, there's my purse.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Now crack thy lungs, and split thy brazen pipe:

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Blow, villain, till thy sphered bias cheek

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Outswell the colic of puff'd Aquilon:

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Come, stretch thy chest and let thy eyes spout blood;

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Thou blow'st for Hector.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Trumpet sounds

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: No trumpet answers.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: 'Tis but early days.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Is not yond Diomed, with Calchas' daughter?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: 'Tis he, I ken the manner of his gait;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: He rises on the toe: that spirit of his

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: In aspiration lifts him from the earth.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Enter DIOMEDES, with CRESSIDA

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Is this the Lady Cressid?

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Even she.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Most dearly welcome to the Greeks, sweet lady.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Our general doth salute you with a kiss.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Yet is the kindness but particular;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: 'Twere better she were kiss'd in general.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: And very courtly counsel: I'll begin.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: So much for Nestor.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: I'll take what winter from your lips, fair lady:

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Achilles bids you welcome.

speaker: MENELAUS
text_entry: I had good argument for kissing once.

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: But that's no argument for kissing now;

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: For this popp'd Paris in his hardiment,

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: And parted thus you and your argument.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: O deadly gall, and theme of all our scorns!

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: For which we lose our heads to gild his horns.

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: The first was Menelaus' kiss; this, mine:

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Patroclus kisses you.

speaker: MENELAUS
text_entry: O, this is trim!

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Paris and I kiss evermore for him.

speaker: MENELAUS
text_entry: I'll have my kiss, sir. Lady, by your leave.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: In kissing, do you render or receive?

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Both take and give.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: I'll make my match to live,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: The kiss you take is better than you give;

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Therefore no kiss.

speaker: MENELAUS
text_entry: I'll give you boot, I'll give you three for one.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: You're an odd man; give even or give none.

speaker: MENELAUS
text_entry: An odd man, lady! every man is odd.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: No, Paris is not; for you know 'tis true,

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: That you are odd, and he is even with you.

speaker: MENELAUS
text_entry: You fillip me o' the head.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: No, I'll be sworn.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: It were no match, your nail against his horn.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: May I, sweet lady, beg a kiss of you?

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: You may.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: I do desire it.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: Why, beg, then.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Why then for Venus' sake, give me a kiss,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: When Helen is a maid again, and his.

speaker: CRESSIDA
text_entry: I am your debtor, claim it when 'tis due.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Never's my day, and then a kiss of you.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Lady, a word: I'll bring you to your father.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Exit with CRESSIDA

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: A woman of quick sense.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Fie, fie upon her!

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: There's language in her eye, her cheek, her lip,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Nay, her foot speaks; her wanton spirits look out

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: At every joint and motive of her body.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: O, these encounterers, so glib of tongue,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: That give accosting welcome ere it comes,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And wide unclasp the tables of their thoughts

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: To every ticklish reader! set them down

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: For sluttish spoils of opportunity

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And daughters of the game.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Trumpet within

speaker: ALL
text_entry: The Trojans' trumpet.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Yonder comes the troop.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Enter HECTOR, armed; AENEAS, TROILUS, and other Trojans, with Attendants

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Hail, all you state of Greece! what shall be done

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: To him that victory commands? or do you purpose

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: A victor shall be known? will you the knights

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Shall to the edge of all extremity

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Pursue each other, or shall be divided

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: By any voice or order of the field?

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Hector bade ask.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Which way would Hector have it?

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: He cares not; he'll obey conditions.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: 'Tis done like Hector; but securely done,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: A little proudly, and great deal misprizing

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: The knight opposed.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: If not Achilles, sir,

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: What is your name?

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: If not Achilles, nothing.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Therefore Achilles: but, whate'er, know this:

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: In the extremity of great and little,

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Valour and pride excel themselves in Hector;

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: The one almost as infinite as all,

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: The other blank as nothing. Weigh him well,

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: And that which looks like pride is courtesy.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: This Ajax is half made of Hector's blood:

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: In love whereof, half Hector stays at home;

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Half heart, half hand, half Hector comes to seek

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: This blended knight, half Trojan and half Greek.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: A maiden battle, then? O, I perceive you.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Re-enter DIOMEDES

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Here is Sir Diomed. Go, gentle knight,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Stand by our Ajax: as you and Lord AEneas

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Consent upon the order of their fight,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: So be it; either to the uttermost,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Or else a breath: the combatants being kin

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Half stints their strife before their strokes begin.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: AJAX and HECTOR enter the lists

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: They are opposed already.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: What Trojan is that same that looks so heavy?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: The youngest son of Priam, a true knight,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Not yet mature, yet matchless, firm of word,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Speaking in deeds and deedless in his tongue;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Not soon provoked nor being provoked soon calm'd:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: His heart and hand both open and both free;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: For what he has he gives, what thinks he shows;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Yet gives he not till judgment guide his bounty,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Nor dignifies an impure thought with breath;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Manly as Hector, but more dangerous;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: For Hector in his blaze of wrath subscribes

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: To tender objects, but he in heat of action

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Is more vindicative than jealous love:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: They call him Troilus, and on him erect

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: A second hope, as fairly built as Hector.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Thus says AEneas; one that knows the youth

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Even to his inches, and with private soul

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Did in great Ilion thus translate him to me.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Alarum. Hector and Ajax fight

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: They are in action.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Now, Ajax, hold thine own!

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Hector, thou sleep'st;

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Awake thee!

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: His blows are well disposed: there, Ajax!

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: You must no more.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Trumpets cease

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: Princes, enough, so please you.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: I am not warm yet; let us fight again.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: As Hector pleases.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Why, then will I no more:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Thou art, great lord, my father's sister's son,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: A cousin-german to great Priam's seed;

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: The obligation of our blood forbids

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: A gory emulation 'twixt us twain:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Were thy commixtion Greek and Trojan so

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: That thou couldst say 'This hand is Grecian all,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: And this is Trojan; the sinews of this leg

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: All Greek, and this all Troy; my mother's blood

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Runs on the dexter cheek, and this sinister

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Bounds in my father's;' by Jove multipotent,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Thou shouldst not bear from me a Greekish member

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Wherein my sword had not impressure made

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Of our rank feud: but the just gods gainsay

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: That any drop thou borrow'dst from thy mother,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: My sacred aunt, should by my mortal sword

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Be drain'd! Let me embrace thee, Ajax:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: By him that thunders, thou hast lusty arms;

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Hector would have them fall upon him thus:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Cousin, all honour to thee!

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: I thank thee, Hector

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Thou art too gentle and too free a man:

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: I came to kill thee, cousin, and bear hence

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: A great addition earned in thy death.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Not Neoptolemus so mirable,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: On whose bright crest Fame with her loud'st Oyes

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Cries 'This is he,' could promise to himself

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: A thought of added honour torn from Hector.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: There is expectance here from both the sides,

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: What further you will do.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: We'll answer it;

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: The issue is embracement: Ajax, farewell.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: If I might in entreaties find success--

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: As seld I have the chance--I would desire

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: My famous cousin to our Grecian tents.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: 'Tis Agamemnon's wish, and great Achilles

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Doth long to see unarm'd the valiant Hector.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: AEneas, call my brother Troilus to me,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: And signify this loving interview

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: To the expecters of our Trojan part;

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Desire them home. Give me thy hand, my cousin;

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: I will go eat with thee and see your knights.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Great Agamemnon comes to meet us here.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: The worthiest of them tell me name by name;

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: But for Achilles, mine own searching eyes

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Shall find him by his large and portly size.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Worthy of arms! as welcome as to one

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: That would be rid of such an enemy;

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: But that's no welcome: understand more clear,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: What's past and what's to come is strew'd with husks

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: And formless ruin of oblivion;

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: But in this extant moment, faith and troth,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Strain'd purely from all hollow bias-drawing,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Bids thee, with most divine integrity,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: From heart of very heart, great Hector, welcome.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: I thank thee, most imperious Agamemnon.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: [To TROILUS]  My well-famed lord of Troy, no

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: less to you.

speaker: MENELAUS
text_entry: Let me confirm my princely brother's greeting:

speaker: MENELAUS
text_entry: You brace of warlike brothers, welcome hither.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Who must we answer?

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: The noble Menelaus.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: O, you, my lord? by Mars his gauntlet, thanks!

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Mock not, that I affect the untraded oath;

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Your quondam wife swears still by Venus' glove:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: She's well, but bade me not commend her to you.

speaker: MENELAUS
text_entry: Name her not now, sir; she's a deadly theme.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: O, pardon; I offend.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: I have, thou gallant Trojan, seen thee oft

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Labouring for destiny make cruel way

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Through ranks of Greekish youth, and I have seen thee,

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: As hot as Perseus, spur thy Phrygian steed,

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Despising many forfeits and subduements,

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: When thou hast hung thy advanced sword i' the air,

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Not letting it decline on the declined,

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: That I have said to some my standers by

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: 'Lo, Jupiter is yonder, dealing life!'

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: And I have seen thee pause and take thy breath,

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: When that a ring of Greeks have hemm'd thee in,

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Like an Olympian wrestling: this have I seen;

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: But this thy countenance, still lock'd in steel,

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: I never saw till now. I knew thy grandsire,

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: And once fought with him: he was a soldier good;

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: But, by great Mars, the captain of us all,

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Never saw like thee. Let an old man embrace thee;

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: And, worthy warrior, welcome to our tents.

speaker: AENEAS
text_entry: 'Tis the old Nestor.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Let me embrace thee, good old chronicle,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: That hast so long walk'd hand in hand with time:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Most reverend Nestor, I am glad to clasp thee.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: I would my arms could match thee in contention,

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: As they contend with thee in courtesy.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: I would they could.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Ha!

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: By this white beard, I'ld fight with thee to-morrow.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Well, welcome, welcome! I have seen the time.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: I wonder now how yonder city stands

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: When we have here her base and pillar by us.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: I know your favour, Lord Ulysses, well.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Ah, sir, there's many a Greek and Trojan dead,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Since first I saw yourself and Diomed

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: In Ilion, on your Greekish embassy.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Sir, I foretold you then what would ensue:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: My prophecy is but half his journey yet;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: For yonder walls, that pertly front your town,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Yond towers, whose wanton tops do buss the clouds,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Must kiss their own feet.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: I must not believe you:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: There they stand yet, and modestly I think,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: The fall of every Phrygian stone will cost

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: A drop of Grecian blood: the end crowns all,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: And that old common arbitrator, Time,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Will one day end it.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: So to him we leave it.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Most gentle and most valiant Hector, welcome:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: After the general, I beseech you next

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: To feast with me and see me at my tent.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: I shall forestall thee, Lord Ulysses, thou!

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Now, Hector, I have fed mine eyes on thee;

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: I have with exact view perused thee, Hector,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: And quoted joint by joint.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Is this Achilles?

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: I am Achilles.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Stand fair, I pray thee: let me look on thee.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Behold thy fill.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Nay, I have done already.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Thou art too brief: I will the second time,

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: As I would buy thee, view thee limb by limb.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: O, like a book of sport thou'lt read me o'er;

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: But there's more in me than thou understand'st.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Why dost thou so oppress me with thine eye?

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Tell me, you heavens, in which part of his body

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Shall I destroy him? whether there, or there, or there?

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: That I may give the local wound a name

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: And make distinct the very breach whereout

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Hector's great spirit flew: answer me, heavens!

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: It would discredit the blest gods, proud man,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: To answer such a question: stand again:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Think'st thou to catch my life so pleasantly

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: As to prenominate in nice conjecture

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Where thou wilt hit me dead?

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: I tell thee, yea.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Wert thou an oracle to tell me so,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: I'd not believe thee. Henceforth guard thee well;

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: For I'll not kill thee there, nor there, nor there;

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: But, by the forge that stithied Mars his helm,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: I'll kill thee every where, yea, o'er and o'er.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: You wisest Grecians, pardon me this brag;

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: His insolence draws folly from my lips;

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: But I'll endeavour deeds to match these words,

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Or may I never--

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Do not chafe thee, cousin:

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: And you, Achilles, let these threats alone,

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Till accident or purpose bring you to't:

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: You may have every day enough of Hector

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: If you have stomach; the general state, I fear,

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Can scarce entreat you to be odd with him.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: I pray you, let us see you in the field:

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: We have had pelting wars, since you refused

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: The Grecians' cause.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Dost thou entreat me, Hector?

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: To-morrow do I meet thee, fell as death;

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: To-night all friends.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Thy hand upon that match.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: First, all you peers of Greece, go to my tent;

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: There in the full convive we: afterwards,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: As Hector's leisure and your bounties shall

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Concur together, severally entreat him.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Beat loud the tabourines, let the trumpets blow,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: That this great soldier may his welcome know.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Exeunt all except TROILUS and ULYSSES

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: My Lord Ulysses, tell me, I beseech you,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: In what place of the field doth Calchas keep?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: At Menelaus' tent, most princely Troilus:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: There Diomed doth feast with him to-night;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Who neither looks upon the heaven nor earth,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: But gives all gaze and bent of amorous view

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: On the fair Cressid.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Shall sweet lord, be bound to you so much,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: After we part from Agamemnon's tent,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: To bring me thither?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: You shall command me, sir.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: As gentle tell me, of what honour was

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: This Cressida in Troy? Had she no lover there

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: That wails her absence?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: O, sir, to such as boasting show their scars

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: A mock is due. Will you walk on, my lord?

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: She was beloved, she loved; she is, and doth:

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: But still sweet love is food for fortune's tooth.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Exeunt
